With just a few short months until the first voters flock to the polls, the former governor is running as a centrist and believes he can unite the party's various voting blocsDemocratic presidential hopeful billionaire and philanthropist Tom Steyer is a longtime Democratic donorwebsite lists a host of objectives such as free-at-the-point-of-use healthcare for all, a jobs guarantee, a cancellation of student debts, a wealth tax on the richest 0.1 per cent and a major investment in public housing and green energy.Wealth taxes? Free health care? A jobs guarantee? Isn’t that socialism?Cardi B and Mark Ruffalo among celebrities backing Bernie SandersWhy the rise of Bernie Sanders is making some Democrats nervousWill bitter moderates vote for Bernie Sanders?But while policies such as free universal healthcare are seen as extreme in the US they are perfectly ordinary in Europe.The higher tax and spending proposed by Sanders would also not be out of place on the other side of the Atlantic.The economist Paul Krugman says Sanders is better described as a European-style social democrat rather than a socialist, not least because Sanders isn’t proposing to nationalise private industries.OK, but would this ruin the American economy?The French economist Thomas Piketty even argues Sanders’&nbsppolicies could be beneficial to the US economy&nbspby raising the country’s growth rate, and says that his wealth distribution policies tap into an older tradition of American policymaking.“Remember that the US is actually the country that invented progressive taxation of income and wealth in the 20th century,” Piketty points out.Others have described Sanders as a “New Dealer”, referring to the progressive economic policies put in place by former&nbspDemocratic President Franklin Roosevelt in the wake of the Great Depression of the 1930s.So why are people describing Sanders as dangerous?But it may also be that the genuinely fear Sanders’ policies, even if they are in the mainstream of the European tradition, will do damage in the US context.Or they may be assuming that Sanders, if he won power, would pursue policies that go much further than those he has proposed, with the 78-year-old proving more radical in office, perhaps like Hugo Chavez in Venezuela.Against this, though, is the institutional fact that US presidents are constrained by Congress in what policies they can enact. Sanders might be in favour of relatively radical redistribution, but that’s not true of the wider Democratic party.Even some of Sanders’ rivals for the Democratic nomination, such as Pete Buttigieg, are critical of his policies such as the $15 federal minimum wage.That’s why many analysts – even those who support the principle of “medicare-for-all” – think there is little chance he could actually deliver it, even if he won power.And while some financiers are sounding the alarm, others are more sanguine.Another Wall Street Bank, JPMorgan, recently told its clients that, even if Sanders were elected, “we put the probability of major changes like medicare-for-all or a wealth tax at less than 5 percent.”All of which raises a question: is the risk less that Sanders ruins the US economy than that he disappoints his supporters?Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Vermont senator&nbspriding high after New Hampshire victory as Nevada loomsBernie Sanders has surged to 31 per cent support nationally in a new poll – his highest rating of the primary season so far.The NPRPBS NewsHourMarist Poll puts him 12 points ahead of his nearest rival, Michael Bloomberg, who will now be joining Sanders and the other primary candidates on the debate stage for the first time.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMr Sanders’s support has grown since he won the New Hampshire primary, where he narrowly defeated former South Bend mayor Pete Buttigeig. He continues to draw huge crowds at his rallies, and last year raised roughly $96m from more than 5 million contributions.However, Mr Sanders faces challenges headed into the next primaries. His campaign for the upcoming Nevada caucuses has been overshadowed by protests from the powerful Culinary Workers Union, the state’s largest labour organisation, which opposes his “Medicare for All” plan.On the other hand, there are signs he is overcoming his past weaknesses as a candidate, in particular by attracting more support from voters of colour.Created with Sketch.Democratic candidates compete on the campaign trail: In pictures Show all 16Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Amy Klobuchar changes her shoes backstage after giving a speech in Exeter, New HampshireA warmly-wrapped-up dog attends an Elizabeth Warren event at Amherst Elementary School in Nashua, New HampshireLisa Olney, of Wellesley, Massachussets, demonstrates her support for Elizabeth Warren in Nashua, New HampshireJoe Biden was hoping to improve on his poor showing in Iowa in the New Hampshire primaryElizabeth Warren, renowned for giving time to supporters for selfies, works the crowd at the University of New Hampshire in DurhamBernie Sanders, who romped to victory in New Hampshire against Hillary Clinton in 2016, talks to the media in ManchesterA man holds up a sign criticising billionaires in the presidential race in front of Michael Bloomberg in Compton, Califronia. title: coronavirus uk live london
story: More than  Brits trapped on board a coronavirus-hit cruise ship in Japan could be flown home, the UK government has confirmed as a British couple have tested positive for the deadly virus.Follow our coronavirus live blog to stay up to date with the latest news and updates on Covid-.Several hundred passengers who have stuck out a -day quarantine on board a bug-ridden cruise liner at a Japanese port may be allowed to disembark tomorrow.But they will also be released from the shipthey have tested negative for the virus.There has been at least  positive cases, with Japanese authorities coming underfire for its handling of arrangements.Passengers on board the Diamond Princess, which has been moored in Yokohama since February , were told in a letter: #If you and your roommate are both negative and have no fever or respiratory symptoms, you will be able to prepare for disembarkation.#Apple Inc is likely to miss its schedule for the mass production of an affordable new iPhone that it planned to release this spring.The tech giant also warned it was unlikely to meet its March quarter sales forecast due to the coronavirus outbreak.Mass production of the model was expected to start by the end of February, but it could now be delayed until sometime in March, reported the Nikkei Asian Review.The company had asked suppliers to ready up to  million units of the cheaper model for the first half of , according to reports late last month.Much of Apples manufacturing operations are based in China,while the company has temporarily closed all it its stores in the virus-stricken country.Footage online shows nurses from the Gansu Provincial Womens and Childrens Hospitalhaving their heads shaved at a ceremony.They had their locks shorn before being sent to Wuhan to treat coronavirus patients. Many people criticised the hospitals requirement, with footage showing the nurses welling up with emotion. The hospital later claimed that all of the workers had volunteered to go completely bald as a way to prevent infection.A spokesperson from the hospital told Red Star News on Monday: #The most important thing is that [going bald] could prevent infection. Also, it is easy [for them] to clean.#EXPERTS say quarantining passengers on a bug-infested cruise ship has created a #boiling pot of transmission# after the number of people testing positive on board tipped over .Dr Anthony Fauci, director of Americas National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, told USA Today that the quarantine process had #failed#.#Id like to sugarcoat it and try to be diplomatic about it, but it failed. People were getting infected on that ship.##Something went awry in the process of the quarantining on that ship. title: the sun says control at last
story: A points system will assess each migrant’s talents. If they meet the threshold and have a job offer paying over an estimated £,, they will be let in.Low-skilled immigration will be slashed.Total numbers will fall.This is what Britain voted for.Even the promise of it has calmed anxiety over immigration since the referendum.So it is incredible to see Labour still champion free movement, even outside the EU.Even more so to hear immigration control branded “racist”.It is literally the opposite.We will no longer block skilled staff from India or Africa while admitting anyone from the EU.Boris Johnson now has a Cabinet focused, as one, on forging our new path as an independent nation.Unity of purpose seems to win elections. It’s the best way to get results too.WHEN will Harry and Meghan settle their debt to Britain, give up their handouts and fund their own security They have sacked their UK staff, are closing their office and clearly have no intention of ing. They have potentially already begun adding to their millions by lecturing rich bankers.Fine. But let’s stop paying them through the Duchy of Cornwall too.It morally belongs to the nation.Let’s see our refund for the Frogmore House refit.The Sussexes cut their ties here. We should cut them loose too.TOUCHED as we are by the House of Lords’ concern over journalism’s future, we do wonderthey have ANY self-awareness.“Public trust in journalists has fallen,” says one peer. “The profession is not representative of the population.”Excuse us  A Press read by millions is supposedly out of touch.But not unelected peers who, after failing to thwart a democratic vote, consoled themselves with an inflation-busting pay rise.Is there an institution more reviled or disconnected than the Lords itself MAYBE “Short Man Syndrome” was John ­Bercow’s problem all along.A study shows that smaller footie refs dish out more yellow cards.Bercow’s not a ref. Merely the author of a spiteful book shortly to be found unsold in charity shops.But the portly little Napoleon was forever issuing ­yellow cards from his Speaker’s perch.Now his nemesis Boris is top of the Premier league. And Bercow is relegated to the stands, alone with his grudges.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rose dont be a thorn in natalies side
story: After all, her incredibly brave allegations of rape and sexual assault levelled at the then all-powerful Miramax boss Harvey Weinstein blazed the trail for the #MeToo movement that emerged in .And she has been a fearless activist ever since, pursuing justice and equality.But I’m afraid it was a dud move on her part to criticise actress Natalie Portman for her decision to walk the red carpet at Sunday night’s Oscars wearing a custom Dior gown and cape, which was adorned with the names of some of the female directors who weren’t nominated this year.In her own way, Natalie wanted to shine a lighton the fact that, for the ninth year in the past decade, all five of the best director nominees were male.The female directors highlighted on Natalie’s gown included Lorene Scafaria , Lulu Wang , Greta Gerwig , Marielle Hellerand Melina Matsoukas .Whatever you think about her way of doing it, there’s no doubt she made a point.And the fact that she was standing on the red carpet made it a more powerful point thanshe had, say, boycotted the event or stood outside with a placard.But in a social media post, Rose McGowan referred to ­Portman’s cape as: “The kind of protest that gets rave reviews from the mainstream media for its ­bravery.”“Brave ”, she wrote. “No, not by a long shot. More like an actress acting the part of someone who cares. As so many of them do.“I find Portman’s type of activism deeply offensive to those of us who actually do the work. I’m not writing this out of bitterness, I am writing out of disgust,” she wrote.Unfortunately, coming from someone who has been so integral in the protest movement, this sounds like sour grapes.Natalie’s response to Rose’s criticism was as elegant and as understated as her protest.She said: “I agree with Ms McGowan that it is inaccurate to call me ‘brave’ for wearing a garment with women’s names on it.“Brave is a term I more strongly associate with actions like those of the women who have been testying against Harvey Weinstein the last few weeks.”She also responded to Rose’s accusation that Natalie has only been directed twice by women.But in this criticism, Rose is seriously missing the point. Female directors don’t get as far in Hollywood as male ones, which is precisely what Natalie is pointing out with her cloak protest. Therefore, there are fewer available to work with.As Natalie said: “It is true I’ve only made a few films with women. In my long career, I’ve only gotten the chance to work with female directors a few times . . . Unfortunately, the unmade films I have tried to make are a ghost history.“Female films have been incredibly hard to get made at studios, or to get independently financed. If these films do get made, women face enormous challenges during the making of them.”By the way, this is not the first time Natalie has protested from within the system.While presenting the best director category at the Golden Globes in , she introduced the line-up by saying: “And here are the all-male nominees.”Again, it’s not a shouty, noisy street protest. But it served to make her point. Just that she did it in a dferent way than Rose might. And that’s fine.In fact, some people think that Rose’s in-your-face type of protest risks alienating some people.I think women should support each other when it comes to vying for equality.But also, Rose just sounded spiteful when she said Natalie was “an actress acting like someone who cares”.Rose is a hero to many women. But she needs to understand that whether their contribution is big or small, loud or subtle, anyone’s effort to affect change helps.JANE Fonda, who looked fabulous at the Oscars, has said she is done with plastic surgery.Well, I guess  is as good an age as any to stop nipping and tucking.She must have a great doctor, as whatever the actress has had done has been done very well indeed – because, in my experience, it’s not often you look better after a facelt than you did before.PERHAPS Andrea Leadsom had a premonition that she was going to be axed as Business Secretary in this week’s Cabinet reshuffle.She recently wrote a column obliquely warning Boris Johnson not to cut the number of female ministers in his Cabinet.Addressing the issue of female board members among FTSE  companies, Andrea wrote: “Working in the City in the Nineties, I saw myself how a male-dominated environment can limit a career.”Unfortunately for her, the warning did not save her skin and she has been sacked, along with Theresa Villiers as Environment Secretary and housing minister Esther McVey.By the way, eight of the  members of Mr Johnson’s first Cabinet were female –  per cent.Despite these sackings, that figure has actually risen – slightly – to nearly  per cent.Ideally, the split would be an even -.But the reality is that business and politics can both be brutal.Men and women alike must accept they might one day get the sack.It simply goes with the territory.Being selected on the basis of gender is just as wrong as being sacked on that basis.Right person, right job, regardless of their gender.THAT is what true equality means.SAY what you like about the bonkers lestyle advice dispensed by Gwyneth Paltrow on Goop – and some of it is seriously out there.But whatever she is doing clearly works.She is, at the age of , nothing short of radiant.In fact she looks amazing and also happy.Not only that but she became instantly relatable to parents everywhere with a confession that her -year- old daughter finds her embarrassing.That’s a good reminder there is nothing like a teenager to keep you normal and down to earth for fear that you will embarrass them, no matter what you do.Although, to be fair, perhaps Gwyneth’s daughter has had a predisposition to feel embarrassed by her mother ever since she named her  . . . Apple.What are the ethics of seat-reclining on a long-haul flight An American Airlines passenger raised the question after video-shaming a fellow traveller who punched and pushed her seat when she reclined it.Bearing in mind the recline button moves the seat about in, I suspect this chap has anger issues, as reclining a seat that has a recline button is hardly an act of aggression.I’d disable the recline button and then all you have to fight over is the armrest.DAMIAN Hurleys resemblance to his mother, Liz, is uncanny.More so than ever in the latest shots of the two of them together, which he posted online this week.Some people think it is vaguely unsettling that he looks more like Liz Hurley than Liz Hurley.But as a mum myself, I think it’s heartwarming a teenage boy should be so happy to emulate his mother.OH the utter folly of the face tattoo!The latest to succumb to this trend, which a few years ago would be, frankly, unthinkable, is Amber Rose.She has had the words Bash and Slash tattooed across her forehead in old English manuscript style.It’s a reference, apparently, to the model’s three-month-old son Slash, and six-year-old son Sebastian. And, obviously, it’s lovely that she loves her children so much.But tattooing their names on her forehead where they will remain for all her le  All I can say is: Tattoo in haste . . . repent at leisure.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan and harry by all means demean yourselves but dont demean our queen
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex owe their global superstar status — and their massive earning potential — to their royal connections.That is the wonderful irony about our runaway royals.Harry and Meghan may despise everything about the royal le — the endless scrutiny, the boring engagements, all those fixed smiles for the peasants when they could be hanging out with Oprah and the Obamas and the Clooneys.We get it. We truly do.But do Harry and Meghan understand and ever admit to themselves that they owe EVERYTHING to their royal connections Without the magic dust that royalty bestows, JP Morgan — one of the world’s richest banks — would never have flown them in a private jet to an exclusive company beano. Don’t tell Greta Thunberg!And without his royal blood, Prince Harry would not be in talks with Goldman Sachs about a future relationship.If they were not British royalty, Meghan would be a B-list actress whom few people had ever heard of and Harry an old soldier with two rotten A-levelsfrom Eton — a school where my dog Stan could get four good grades and an offer from Oxbridge.I do not doubt Harry and Meghan’s sincerity when they say they want to be financially independent.But because they are poncing on royal connections, the couple have a duty of care to the Queen and to this country.Please don’t embarrass the Royal Family, or British people who shelled out £million for your wedding.Please do not turn into the preening glove puppets of investment bankers.Oh Harry, please don’t turn into Tony Blair in a tiara.Oh Meghan, don’t become the st-century Fergie.Prince Andrew’s reckless friendship with convicted billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein has humiliated and damaged the Royal Family.Andrew’s total lack of judgment may have done irreparable harm to the monarchy.Many of us wonderthe institution will last after the Queen has gone.So show some dignity, Harry and Meghan. Engage your brains, not your bank balance.Have a little DISCRETION. Please do not pimp your royal connections to any passing dodgy billionaire or investment banker who claims to care deeply about your charity work.Frankly, it doesn’t look good so far.The nation cringed when Prince Harry buttonholed Disney boss Bob Iger at the London premiere of The Lion King, aggressively pitching Meghan’s availability for “voiceover” work.A member of the Royal Family begging a Hollywood big-shot for work was not a pretty sight.When they handed in their letter of resignation, Harry and Meghan made lofty announcements about “collaborating” with the Queen, as though Her Majesty, , is some grime DJ who could be brought in to remix their latest single.The brutal truth is that we will not see much of Harry and Meghan in these parts.This week they sacked  loyal UK staff and shut their Buckingham Palace office.But by turning their backs on the royal le, Harry and Meghan have placed themselves in an almost impossible situation.They claim to want to be financially independent of Prince Charles and the British taxpayer.Then they will have to grab the big pay days where they can.They will have to earn phenomenal sums of money to fund the lavish lestyle to which they are accustomed.But there is absolutely nothing in either of their CVs to suggest they can make that kind of dough without flogging their royal connections to the highest bidder.If Harry and Meghan are going to support themselves, they are going to have to get their hands dirty in the working world.Harry’s discussions with Goldman Sachs may be focused on his charity work right now, but investment bankers are not renowned for their boundless human compassion.Big bankers — and mega-rich companies like Netflix and Apple — will look at Harry and Meghan and wonder what they can get out of them.Harry and Meghan are free to demean themselves, as Harry did so spectacularly when he shook his diamond-encrusted begging bowl at the boss of Disney.But please don’t demean this country.Please don’t debase the Royal Family, as Prince Andrew has done.Please, Harry and Meghan — do not embarrass the Queen.Because let’s face it, chaps — without your royal connections, the pair of you really don’t add up to very much at all.After all those wild decades, Keith – who is said to have smoked an estimated , fags in his time – clearly believes in moderation in all things.Especially moderation in moderation.IN a pithy turn of phrase worthy of Oscar Wilde, one commentator mused that Labour’s dishevelled Tracy Brabin looked like she had been “banged over a wheelie bin” in her off-the-shoulder frock in the House of Commons.Showing Tracy how it is done, Kate Beckinsale looked stunning in a very similar off-the-shoulder number at a pre-Oscars party.Kate also looks as though she has never even seen a wheelie bin.But it’s not true. I recall Debbie Harry was a dazzling double NME winner in  – Pin-Up Of The Year and Best Female Singer.The NME may be  years old. But NME award winners never get any older.THE coronavirus could well be China’s Chernobyl – the national calamity that changes everything.As the global death toll of the virus nears ,, the old men in Beijing who run China have never looked so woefully out of their depth.The greatest hero in China today is Dr Li Wenliang, the -year-old Wuhan doctor who tried to warn the Communist regime of the virus.Dr Li was arrested, bullied, humiliated, accused of scaremongering and later died of the virus.That is what happens in a one-party state that considers all criticism to be treason.China does not look like the next economic superpower today.China looks like an inept one-party state that failed to grasp the seriousness of the virus, then stubbornly refused to heed the warnings that could have contained it, and has now exported it to the rest of the world.The coronavirus came out of the so-called wet markets of China, where every conceivable animal is kept in filthy conditions to cater for the Chinese appetite for “exotic” animals.Wolf pups, koala bears and assorted rats, bats and snakes are all on offer for the discerning wildle gourmet, many under the counter.These markets were the breeding ground for Sars nearly  years ago, and they were the breeding ground for the coronavirus.Exactly how stupid can a regime be that allows the existence of these unregulated markets  The virus that is now polluting the entire planet was totally avoidable.Mikhail Gorbachev was convinced that the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl in  caused the collapse of the Soviet Union five years later.The Chernobyl explosion “opened the possibility of much greater freedom of expression”, said Gorbachev. “To the point that the system as we knew it could no longer continue.”If the coronavirus brings down China’s ruling Communist elite, it will be exactly what they deserve.Now Leo has seen his Fine Gael party poll a wretched . per cent of the vote in the Irish general election, going from power to third place overnight.Looks like Leo Varadkar is a teeny-weeny politician now.Now BBC chairman David Clementi squeaks that ending the licence fee will mean scrapping children’s channel CBeebies.Stop our money and you will make all the kiddies cry!But the openly biased BBC stopped being a state broadcaster years ago.It no longer deserves to be funded like one.TANYA McDonnell is a modern success story.Tanya was working in McDonald’s in Washington, Tyne-and-Wear, for £ an hour until a modelling agency spotted her holiday shots on Instagram.“I’d always looked up to people like Kate Moss,” says Tanya. “But I didn’t think I had a chance because I wasn’t pretty enough.”Only in the age of social media could a girl go from having her picture taken on holiday to making a living as a model.And only in the age of social media could someone who looks like Tanya McDonnell fret that she is not pretty enough.I didn’t know he had one.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL title: caroline flack honesty sunshine our life inspired
story: She was also one of the most honest.Unlike so many of our cosseted household names she was approachable, witty and refreshingly open about her own le and struggles.She spoke with candour about her career and her personal le.She was unafraid to open up about her fears and in that way she inspired fans to be open and honest about the problems we all face in le at dferent times.She was a brilliant host of Love Island — funny and insightful without ever being patronising towards the contestants.Her untimely death is a tragedy, the third associated with the show and its future must now be in doubt.The Crown Prosecution Service needs to take a long look in the mirror and ask why it pursued its course of action given what they knew about her vulnerability.We may never know exactly what drove Caroline over the edge.But we will always remember how, like the weather at the TV villa, she brought so much sunshine into our lives.The Duchess of Cambridge’s candour about the joys and pressures of motherhood is to be applauded.Kate’s moving honesty in a new podcast about her feelings of loneliness and “mum guilt” will chime with women across the country.And the fact our future Queen has expressed her feelings so publicly shows how she is subtly modernising the monarchy as well as gaining in self- confidence.The contrast with Meghan and Harry’s complaints about being in the media spotlight will not be lost on the public.While the Sussexes have quit their Royal duties, Kate has kept working hard for her husband and the “firm”.She had to put up with years of jibes about her family and fashion sense, but the nation has now taken her to its heart.We are lucky – and proud – to have this Duchess of Dignity.BRITAIN’S standards in areas like the environment, the minimum wage and workers’ rights are higher than many EU countries.But Brussels is bizarrely demanding that we LOWER our internationally admired regulationswe want to sign up to its tarf-free trade deal.Boris must stick to his mantra of levelling up, not levelling down, and resist the Eurocrats’ race to the bottom.Anything  would betray voters.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make title: brexit points based immigration system
story: This Government promised to get Brexit done and we delivered.But that wasn’t our only promise you overwhelmingly backed at the ballot box.We also promised to deliver a points-based immigration system that delivers for the whole of the United Kingdom and this week we will set out plans do just that.On Friday, the new Cabinet backed mine and the Prime Minister’s vision to take back control of who comes to this country.We agreed a radical, new, firm but fair system that rewards the skills people have to offer, not where they come from.Sun on Sunday readers have been with us on this journey.And I can make another promise, that you will finally have an immigration system that works in the interests of our country.For too long firms have relied on cheap, foreign low-skilled labour rather than investing in our workers.They have exploited free movement to undercut you, taking away jobs and driving down wages.For too long we were powerless to help, shackled by Europe and forced to be rule-takers. Ending free movement changes all that.The Government has listened to the clear message from the  referendum and the  General Election that the public wants a reduction in low-skilled immigration.We want to see overall numbers down and this new system will deliver. Our new immigration system will turn off the tap of cheap, foreign low-skilled labour.Workers coming to the UK will have to prove they have something to offer.We are not closing our doors, but we will finally be able to choose who comes through them.We will attract the top talent from anywhere in the world.Allowing us to attract the brightest and the best from around the globe who will help our economy to thrive.From next year, all skilled workers will need to earn enough points to work in the UK.They will need to speak English, have a firm job offer, and meet the salary requirements.Extra points will be awarded to people who have the most to offer, including those working in a profession where there is a real skills shortage.We will continue to monitor – through expert advisers –there are shortages and gaps to be filled.For those coming to work in our NHS and schools, points will be awarded in line with pay scales for their professions.This is only the beginning, and this week we will set out our plans to go even further with a system to deliver the reforms you want.For the first time in decades, the UK will have control over who comes to our great country and how our immigration system works.We’ve got Brexit done, now we’re moving on to focus on the people’s other priorities.We promised to unleash our country’s full potential and we are doing just that. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc licence fee leo mckinstry abolish
story: The creaking corporation is almost a century old, and nowhere is that more apparent than in its defence of the hopelessly outdated licence fee.The Beeb likes to pose as a beacon of fairness, yet it is subsidised by a draconian compulsory charge that should have no place in a modern free society.On pain of criminal prosecutions, all owners of television sets are forced to bankroll BBC staff, regardless of whether they ever use its services or not.Lets be clear: it is fundamentally wrong that people should have to pay for something they do not want.That is why the Government is right to consider the abolition of the licence fee within the next few years, moving to a subscription-based service.Such a move, which could happen before the BBC’s charter is renewed in , would be entirely in step with our times.After all, nearly half of British households already subscribe to streaming channels like Netflix. And more people now watch YouTube than all terrestrial broadcasters put together.Even the BBCs highest paid star, Gary Lineker, says its time to make the fee voluntary, while Dame Helen Mirren admits its had its day.Yet the Government’s policy has provoked howls of outrage, especially from the chattering liberals who seem to regard the licence fee as a sacred part of our constitution.Their squeals of protest are badly misplaced. The fact is that, by guaranteeing a huge revenue stream, the licence fee promotes a culture of excess and mismanagement within the BBC, which has a budget of almost £ billion and employs , people.Its reflected in the vast salaries paid to scores of BBC stars, far beyond market rates, like the £. million previously dished out to Lineker, £, to newsreader Huw Edwards, or the £, to sports presenter Jason Mohammad.You can spot it in the host of botched or extravagant schemes, like the notorious reconstruction of the EastEnders set, whose budget soared from £ million to £. million.Worse still, a staggering £ billion was spent on the refurbishment of Broadcasting House in central London.There is also absurd doubling up among staff, particularly in the news.Last week, the BBC had  correspondents covering the American Democrat primaries in Iowa and New Hampshire, while in  no fewer than  on-air journalists were sent to report on one brief Brussels summit attended by David Cameron.But the lack of any commercial pressure is most easily spotted in the vast, sprawling tiers of flabby bureaucracy.Ab Fab comedian Jenner Saunders once said of the corporation, “It’s become top-heavy in such an ugly way,” adding that it is “an executive-run place for idiots”.A glance through the BBC’s Annual Report for  shows just how correct she was.On these pages, I counted no fewer than eight managers who had “Human Resources Director” in their job titles, all of them on at least £,-a-year.Among them were: Dale Haddon, “HR Director, News and Employee Relations”, on up to £, Rachel Currie, “BBC Group HR Director” on up to £, and Gillian Taylor, “HR Director” on £,.It was the same story with BBC News, whose regiment of well-healed officials included: Fran Unsworth, the “Director of News” on £, Gavin Allen, “Head of News Output” on £, and Jonathan Munroe, Head of Newsgathering” on £,.This grasping spirit prevails throughout the bloated organisation, from the £, “Director of Nations and Regions” to the £, “Director of Radio and Education.”Insulated by public funding, the corporation adores both navel-gazing and self-promotion. So it has a “Director of Communications” on £,-a-year, a “Director of Policy” on £, and a “Director of Editorial Policy” on £,.All that puts into perspective the current moans from the BBC about the need for cuts.But apart from the managerial excess, what also aggravates is how the corporation uses its publicly-funded muscle to promote a fashionable, London-centric agenda.As the state’s monopoly broadcaster, the BBC should be utterly impartial.Yet its output is dominated by trendy political messages on immigration, climate change, Tory cuts, ersity and poverty.The BBC might have lavished reporters on the Democrat primaries, but it gave hardly any live coverage to the recent celebrations in Parliament Square at the moment of Brexit.Typically a Newsnight discussion  that evening – held in a studio bedecked with the blue and gold of the EU - featured two Remainers and one Brexiteer.Left-wing propaganda is continually crowbarred into everything from drama to discussion programmes.Just  per cent of the national workforce is employed in the public sector, yet the BBC is filled with the voices of state employees, most of them whining about under-funding.Left-wing opinions have a stranglehold most topical comedy shows, such as Radio Four’s News Quiz, hosted by the achingly unfunny Nish Kumar.It was Kumar who recently caused a storm by sneeringly presenting an edition of the BBC children’s show “Horrible Histories”, in which Britain’s Victorian past was held up for ridicule.The BBC can get away with this because of its lucrative monopoly as the state’s only broadcaster. It has abused that privileged position for too long.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: aussie cops search well brit backpacker
story: Politician Frank Pangallo said police did not check the well properly because it was flooded at the time — even though a van similar to the killer’s was spotted next to it.The well is just a mile from where Peter and girlfriend Joanne Lees were ambushed.Falconio, from Huddersfield, vanished in  but his body was never found.Killer Bradley Murdoch waved down Peter and Joanne, both , and Peter was shot dead.Joanne hid for five gruelling hours before flagging down a van and escaping.Falconios body, the gun used to shoot him and a jacket belonging to Joanne were never found.Australian politician and former journalist, Frank Pangallo visited the well twice as part of a years-long investigation.According to The Mirror, a forensic anthopologist told Pangello the well was the perfect place to hide a body.The lead investigator on the case said the well was searched, but Charlie Frith who owns the millions of acres of land where the well is located insists cops didnt investigate properly.He said: They half went down it. I don’t knowthey didn’t have the right gear, but they didn’t get to the bottom.He added no-body has ever been back but it would not be too hard to search again.The assistant police commissioner on the original case said it would be strange not to re-visit the well.Police Comissioner, John Dalby added Murdoch refuses to say where Peters body is.He added: I’d like to see the whole thing resolved. It’s still open-ended.Northern Territory Police said: “We’ve commenced an assessment of information records with focus on names and location which have been provided.”A four-part Channel  series revisits the case later this year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brit couple trapped coronavirus cruise ship positive
story: David, , and Sally Abel are among the  Brits on the Diamond Princess liner since it docked in Japan on February  after an outbreak of the virus.David has spent the last two weeks begging the UK government to take action and rescue British nationals on board in his daily social media posts.The couple sons Steven has told This Morning that the quarantine has been a failure after his parents were struck down with the bug in the last  hours.He said: All I want now is for the UK authorities to still go and get them.I know they have tested positive but whatever they are doing in Japan...why cant that happen here in the UK.Steven said that when he FaceTimed his parents today he was unable to speak to his dad David because he was vomiting.He said his father has underlying health problems including type- diabetic for which he is insulin-dependent.Steven, who was speaking via video-link from Salford, Greater Manchester, said David has a tooth infection which combined with his diabetes could be more serious than the virus itself..With only a day left of their -day isolation on board the ship, and after saying hed “never felt less loved by my own country, the David and Sally have been struck down by the killer bug.Only this morning have the UK Foreign Office said they are working to organise a flight back to the UK for Brits stuck on the ship - which has become infested with the virus since it docked two weeks ago.For David and Sally its too little too late.Writing on Facebook today, David said: There is going to be a time of quiet. We have been proved positive and leaving for hospital soon. Blessings all xxxAnd he later said they werent going to hospital - but were being taken instead to a hostel to be isolated.He wrote: That’s where partners are sent waiting out their quarantine. No phone, no wi-fi and no medical facilities.He and his we, from Oxfordshire, had been desperately appealing for help to get off the cruise - even tweeting Sir Richard Branson in an attempt to be saved.And he has repeatedly criticised UK authorities for not acting fast enough to rescue them.He said: Dont you want the English people home “I am always proud to be British but this now - its gone beyond a joke, Ive never felt less loved by my own country.David and Sally are among  people confirmed to have the deadly bug on the cruise ship in the last  hours - taking the total number of those infected on the boat to above .The revelation they have tested positive for coronavirus comes just one day before their quarantine on the Diamond Princess was due to end.About  Brits were on board the cruise ship before the outbreak.Around , passengers on the UK-flagged luxury liner have been confined to their cabins since it docked in Yokohama, Japan, earlier this month.A Number  spokesman said: We sympathise with all those caught up in this extremely dficult situation.The Foreign Office is in contact with all British people on the Diamond Princess, including to establish interest in a possible repatriation flight.We are urgently considering all options to guarantee the health and safety of those on board.There were initially , passengers trapped on board but some have been taken off the cruise in Yokahoma to be treated for the killer bug.Those who remained on the ship were told their quarantine would be over on February  after the official two-week isolation period.The global death toll is currently at ,.Up to  million people have been forced into indefinite lockdown in Chinas Hubei province - the region at the centre of the outbreak.The coronavirus was first detected in the city of Wuhan in the central Chinese province in December.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum partner dying street jog
story: Laura Rudd, , launched a frantic hunt for Nigel Glanville, , heading out to look for him with their two-year-old son Noah.But Nigel had collapsed with a heart attack and died near their home in Grimsby, North East Lincolnshire on February .Heartbroken Laura has now launched an appeal to stop the law treating unmarried partners like second-class citizens when their loved one dies.Laura, , told Manchester Evening News: I found the ambulance when I went out to look for him with our little boy, Noah, and from there, our world came crashing down.“I lost the love of my le and our little boy lost his daddy at an age when he is far too young to grasp what that means.He just thinks his daddy is hiding and keeps asking when he is going to come home.”On Valentines Day, Laura had to register Nigels death and organise his funeral.She also discovered that even though she and Nigel were together for nine years, the law does not recognise them as a couple.Laura had to register him as a single man and could not be his next of kin, registering as the person organising the funeral.Laura, who worked as a teacher in Franklin College and the Grimsby Institute, said: It was a truly low point in the worst week of my le.“According to the law, I dont count. I even had to register him as ‘single’.It was a spit in the face for nearly a decade spent together, simply because in the eyes of the law Noah and I aren’t even recognised.Laura blasted the soul destroying discrimination against unmarried parents when a partner dies.If the couple were married or in a civil partnership, she would have be entitled to financial support to help cover the cost of his funeral and raise Noah.Six months ago, the couple bought a house together in Wilberfoss, East Yorkshire and were planning on getting married.Laura said: Times have changed and people are not getting married like they used to. Many people who are together are choosing to delay getting married until they are financially stable or choosing not to do it at all.There are millions of people across the country who have the same relationship that Nigel and I had, and I just hope that they never have to feel the unnecessary pain that I have been through.The couple had a le insurance policy but Laura has been unable to access any other financial support.She says the law treats many couples struck by tragedy as second-class citizens.Laura said: “Words cannot describe just how angry I am about it all.Laura has launched a petition to put try and pressure on the government to change the law.Laura’s Equality in Grief appeal intends to address two issues: being able to register someone as part of a cohabiting couple when registering a death and giving cohabiting couples with children the same rights and access to financial support as married couples, such as the bereavement payment.Laura said: “It wont bring Nigel back to us, butit means no one  has to go through this then it will be worth the effort.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince andrew fbi demand jeffrey epstein
story: The embattled Duke of York has been told step up...reveal what you know after it emerged he visited a second tycoon facing child sex charges.Andrew reportedly stayed in Peter Nygards mansion in the Bahamas with ex-we Sarah Ferguson in .The billionaire tycoon, , is accused of raping  teens but strongly denies the allegations and there is no suggestion Andrew knew of his alleged criminality.But in the wake of the new claims, Lisa Bloom - the lawyer for Epsteins victims - has urged Andrew to speak to the FBI, the Mirror reports.She said: Now, more than ever, it is essential that you co-operate. title: labour leadership hopeful lisa nandy vows to scrap the monarchy
story: Ms Nandy put the Royal Family on the chopping block, breaking ranks from her fellow candidates in a debate between the final three last night.Ms Nandy was asked point blank on Channel s leadership debate about whether she would vote for getting rid of the monarchya referendum was held.She said: Im a democrat so I would vote to scrap it.This is not our priority as a country, weve just left the EU without any kind of plan about where were going next.She joked she would quite like to see Queen Meghan at some point.Ms Nandys comments come after Meghan Markle and Prince Harry announced they were stepping back as senior members of the royal family. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex caused a major fracture in the royal family when they decided to move to Canada and leave their duties behind.Leadership race frontrunner Sir Keir Starmer said he would not get rid of the royals entirely but would downsize them.He said: I wouldnt , I think Id downsize it.Weve been talking about why we lost the election and what we need to do next - this isnt one of the priorities for the leader of the Labour Party.Leftie contender Rebecca Long-Bailey said it was not a priority for voters and she would not vote to get rid of them.Tory MP Andrea Jenkyns slammed Ms Nandys position on scrapping the royals.She wrote on twitter: Ridiculous! The monarchy is at the core of our constitutional values and the Queen is the beating heart of our nation. More proof that Labour are out of touch and should focus on the issues!Sir Keir took the lions share of nominations in the last round of the leadership race and the competition was whittled down to three after Emily Thornberry failed to get enough backing for her bid to be leader. Labour Party members now have until April  to vote for their next leader.The results will be announced on April , and disastrous leader Jeremy Corbyn will finally step down.

title: prince harry meghan markle sacked aides
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex fired all  members of their very loyal team in a sign they plan never toto Britain after quitting as royals.It is believed that while a couple of their team may find work in the royal household, the bulk will now be negotiating their redundancy packages in a clean break.A source today told The Sun Online today: Those who worked for Harry and Meghan were very much in their style, many of them were headhunted from highly successful jobs in the private sector.The idea that they could simply be moved into a Palace role isn’t going to work.Many of them were attracted by the fact they were working for Harry and Meghan who liked to do things dferently.They added: There are a lot of cliques that exist within the teams who work as advisers for the Royals. title: jars of preserved human tongues dating back 50 years are found hidden in house
story: The large white containers were discovered in a crawlspace, under the floorboards of the home, local news station WCJB reported Monday.They were found during an inspection of a house in Gainesville, Fla., and some of them date back to the s.Each jar is labeled with a name and date and reportedly holds about one gallon.At least six jars contained formaldehyde and body parts. Some contained human tongues.According to WCJB, a former University of Florida researcher at one time owned the house.The retired professor, Dr. Ronald A. Baughman, published studies in the s and s.Hours after the frightening Monday discovery, a man claiming to be the home inspector who notied police wrote to Reddit: Today I was inspecting a crawl space for foundation issues. Once I crawled in I saw quite a few old children’s toys.Lots of old construction debris as well. All well aged, covered in dust, spider webs and mold.Further in I discovered - plastic jars. I looked at them and noticed masking tape with a single name on each. First names. Human names like Angela, Heather, Virginia, etc.I was going to continue the inspection, but … those first names didn’t sit right with me.He added: I went back and found that one jar was rusted through on top. Inside I saw a plastic bag and immediately what looked like small bones.I removed the bag and almost immediately realized it was actually a small infant child. Her first name written on the exterior. The details of her little face were still very much preserved.The unidentied man later shared footage of the container to Reddit, which apparently contained human tongues.When the man described photographing the jugs and tongues, he said he thought they were dead mice.Gainesville Police are investigating the jars as they may be related to Baughmans work.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the bbc is untrustworthy licence fee choice
story: THE culture war over the BBC licence fee is in full force.And predictably the usual campaign from the typical Beeb scare mongers has begun.So let me start by saying: No one is suggesting closing the BBC. No one is suggesting you won’t have Strictly Come Dancing or Match of the Day or even Question Time and Newsnight.But the media is fundamentally changing. Consumer choice – what you or me choose to consume on the box or on our iPads or phones and at what time – is king.The idea that by  paying £. for a service that we may choose not to watch or listen to AT ALL is insanity.It might be unpleasant for BBC lers but the time has come to accept that the licence fee must evolve into a subscription service, so that the corporation is accountable to viewers and not the current behemoth that puts local newspapers out of business, that competes with national newspaper websites to write about Love Island, and that makes podcasts like Reality Tea all about the MTV reality series Geordie Shore.That is NOT public service broadcasting. It is a blatant and constant attempt to undercut struggling commercial rivals.But a sea change is coming. I truly feel it.Sure, there might be disagreement at Downing Street about exactly what that change will involve.Personally I’m on the side of Dominic Cummings who wants wholescale cuts. Sell Radio  and Radio , shut down the sweeping BBC Online department and focus on true public service programming that won’t be provided where. Then in  allow people the choice about whether they want to pay for what they watch from the BBC or not.But the plan by Boris Johnson - who The Times reports this morning fancies an evolution not a revolution - is also valid. story: The clip was filmed on a flight from Oujda, Morocco to Brussels, Belgium, which became caught in a strong flow of turbulence on Sunday.In the footage, people are seen holding on the seats in front of them as the plane rocks from side to side uncontrollably.As the shaking gets worse, passengers are heard crying and praying fearing the worst.One person is even heard gagging although it’s unclearthey actually vomited.The plane eventually landed in Charleroi airport while Storm Dennis raged.Meanwhile, heart-stopping footage emerged yesterday of the moment a ferry lurches sideways after being battered by high winds and violent waves caused by Dennis.Almost on the verge of capsizing, the dramatic footage shows the CalMac ferry battling against mph crosswinds as it attempted to find post in Ardrossan Harbour, Scotland, on Friday.Storm Dennis sparked danger to le flood warnings as it punished the country with fierce rain and gales over the weekend.Three people fell victim to the storm as a months worth of rain fell in just  hours and winds were recorded at a staggering speed of mph.While the storm battered most parts of Britain, the crew on board the MV Caledonian in Scotland were forced to take evasive action during the adverse weather.The scary -second clip was captured by onlooker William Campbell.Clearly unphased by it all, he later boarded the ferry and joked that his journey was a wee bit choppy.He told the BBC that he was used to rough weather, but speculated that some would-be visitors might have been put off.After the boat fought against violent waves and fierce winds created by the storm, the managing director of CalMac, Robbie Drummond, took to Twitter to praise its crew for their skilful navigation.He wrote: All credit to the skill of our masters and one to consider for those pressing CalMac to take more risk.Safety of our passengers and crew is always our top priority.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nandos refuses seat customer waiter name mr chicken

title: eu chiefs elgin marbles brexit trade talks
story: Athens won a new demand in Michel Barnier’s mandate for the “ of unlawfully removed cultural objects to their countries of origin”.But the move infuriated No  which accused the EU of showing a “troubling lack of seriousness about the negotiations” over future relations.A senior Downing St source fumed: “It’s just not happening. The Elgin Marbles are going nowhere.”And a UK Government spokesman insisted: “This is not up for discussion as part of our trade negotiations.”Ex Culture Minister Ed Vaizey said any attempts to “strong-arm” No  would be a “non-starter” as the British Museum owns the marbles.The row risked souring relations between the two sides a fortnight to the day before talks are set to open.Greece has repeatedly lobbied for the repatriation of the ,-year-old sculptures which were taken from the Parthenon over  years ago.Last month the country’s culture minister Lina Mendoni said Brexit had created “the right conditions for their permanent ”.EU sources denied the clause was just about the marbles and said it is targeted at trade in antiquities through London’s auction houses.A Greek Government spokesman said its request for their“is eternal, not tied to a Brexit trade deal”.A British Museum spokesman added: “The British Museum welcomes this mandate and is committed to fighting the trade in illicit antiquities across the world.“The Parthenon Sculptures were legally acquired and help us to tell the story of human history presented at the Museum.The demand comes on the back of Spain exploiting the withdrawal negotiations to pursue its agenda over Gibraltar.The th Earl of Elgin, Thomas Bruce, removed the Parthenon Marble pieces from the Acropolis in Athens while serving as the British ambassador to the Ottoman Empire from  to .He requested that the Turks, who had previously conquered Greece and occupied the country, to take away the works of Greek art so he could put them in his London home.Lord Elgin obtained authority to take away sculptures or inscriptions on the grounds that the removal didnt interfere the walls or works of the building.In , the sculptures were removed from the temple and transported to England. The Scottish aristocrat was accused of looting and vandalism.They were kept in storage in a damp, dirty shed at Elgins Park Lane house for two years while he was in prisoned in France.Finally, nearly a decade of being kept in innapropriate conditions, the government bought the marbles in  to be put on display in the British Museum.In , a Labour MP asked Winston Churchill whether the marbles would be ed to Greece and the answer was no.Greece has fought for theirfor years but with no success.The authenticity of Elgins permit to remove the sculptures from the Parthenon has been widely disputed, especially as the original document has been lost. Many claim it was not legal.However, others argue that since the Ottomans had controlled Athens since , their claims to the artefacts were legal and recognisable.The controversy erupted as Michel Barnier hit back at the PM’s chief negotiator over a speech in which he called for a Canada-style deal.He said David Frost was wrong to describe the bloc’s demands the UK respects EU standards as anti-democratic.And he warned that the Britain cannot have trading access on the same terms as Canada because it is much closer to Europe.The Frenchman said: “It is a sovereign decision of the EU, it is a sovereign decision of the UK to cooperate.“We have proposed a trade agreement with a country that has a very particular and unique close geographical proximity, not like Canada.”The Commission also pushed back against Mr Frost’s criticisms of its Level Playing Field demand, saying that “distance matters in trade”.A spokeswoman said: “Every trade deal we do has a level playing field element tailored to the specic circumstances of our partners.“Each deal depends on a number of dferent factors, including distance, and the level and intensity of trade we have with that particular country.”Meanwhile Brussels’ trade boss, Phil Hogan, said that Mr Johnson would have to take “full responsibility” for any trade frictions after Brexit.He said: “It’s up to the UK to make sure it doesn’t happen. We’re looking for a level playing field and they don’t seem to want it.”The Irishman added that Boris Johnson’s plan to erge from EU rules after Brexit is a “big worry” for British manufacturers.Yesterday it emerged that the first round of the trade negotiations will take place in Brussels not London.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit negotiator britain hardline eu rules
story: He compared Britain to a guest “who had enough at the party and was trying to find a way to slip out”.And he told the Brussels audience: “We were already in the hallway.”Mr Frost insisted Britain is not frightened by warnings of extra friction in trade, saying the costs had been exaggerated and so too had the benefits of tarf-free trade.He said Mr Johnsons Government understands the trade-offs involved and revealed they will be publishing a detailed blueprint for our future relationship next week.In his forthright speech he warned Brussels they Brexit would make the UK more agile and its independence would allow the Government to correct bad decisions much easier and quicker. Mr Frost said: The EU is going find this much, much more dficult.He added: Looking forward, we are going to have a huge advantage over the EU – the ability to set regulations for new sectors, the new ideas, and new conditions – quicker than the EU can, and based on sound science not fear of the future.I have no doubt that we will be able to encourage new investment and new ideas in this way – particularly given our plans to boost spend on scientic research, attract scientists and make Britain the best country in the world to do science. And hammering home the message that Mr Johnson is not bluffing when he says he will not be signing up to EU level playing-field rules, Mr Frost said: Independence does not mean a limited degree of freedom infor accepting some of the norms of the central power.It means – independence – just that. I recognise that some in Brussels might be uncomfortable with that – but the EU must,it is to achieve what it wants in the world, find a way of relating to its neighbours as friends and genuinely sovereign equals.Europe’s leaders have insisted we sign up to a “level playing field” on workers’ rights and state bailouts as the price for a trade deal.Mr Frost said Boris Johnson’s stand “isn’t a simple negotiating position which might move under pressure”.Warning the PM will instead walk away without a deal, he insisted: “We bring not some clever tactical positioning but the fundamentals of what it means to be an independent country.”He added of being in the EU: “We never knew what we really wanted to achieve other than stop other countries do what other countries wanted to do.“It’s so bizarre people told themselves Britain was winning the arguments or the EU is a British project. It’s clearly not.”And it’s ludicrous for the  EU nations to pretend “alignment” is necessary.The bloc removed . per cent of tarf lines in its trade deal with Korea, and  per cent in its deal with Japan.These countries don’t have to follow the EU’s trade rules, so why on earth should Britain We would welcome a deal with the EU,it could be agreed on reasonable terms. Butthe bloc is determined to punish us for Brexit, then let it try.Britain’s economy is flourishing, optimism is high, and we’re hurtling towards our first trade dealat breakneck speed.If push comes to shove, we can thrive without a UK EU trade deal. Could the EU Mr Frost said it is wrong to try to tie Britain to more than the EU asked of Canada or Japan in trade deals.He said: “My experience is that EU has extreme dficulty in correcting wrong decisions.”Nigel Farage said: “Great speech by David Frost in Brussels, the UK Government is sticking to the promises.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: andrew sabisky eugenics controversy
story: Heres what we know about the self-proclaimed super forecaster.Andrew Sabisky, , was brought in to work as a contractor on Downing Street projects in early . He previously called for children to be given mind-altering drugs.Sabisky has also advocated enforced contraception to stop teenage pregnancies and said giving children mental performance-enhancing drugs is probably worth “a dead kid once a year”.And he also publicly described Education Secretary Gavin Williamson and Cabinet Office minister Penny Mordaunt as “morons”.Prior to his resignation the government was facing calls to sack Sabisky after he controversially preached that black people are less intelligent than whites.He resigned amid mounting fury among Tory MPs over Boris Johnsons decision to stand by Sabisky.Before the atrocities of Nazi Germany, eugenics – the system of measuring human traits, seeking out the desirable ones and cutting out the undesirable ones – was once practised the world over.Sabisky has sparked controversy with his remarks.In a comment on a  blog post on Dominic Cummings website, made by a user called Andrew Sabisky, it is suggested that compulsory contraception could be used to stop a permanent underclass.It read: One way to get around the problems of unplanned pregnancies creating a permanent underclass would be to legally enforce universal uptake of long-term contraception at the onset of puberty.Vaccination laws give it a precedent, I would argue.Then, on another website in , a post by what appears to be the same user suggested black Americans had a lower average IQ than white Americans.A user with the same name later commented on a dferent blog that:There are excellent reasons to think the very real racial dferences in intelligence are signicantly - even mostly - genetic in origin, though the degree is of course a very serious subject of scholarly debate.Sabisky also suggested to Schools Week in July  that the benefits of a purported cognitive enhancer, which can prove fatal, are probably worth a dead kid once a year.He added: Eugenics are about selecting for good things.Intelligence is largely inherited and it correlates with better outcomes: physical health, income, lower mental illness.The -year-old academic was hired by the PM’s chief aide Dominic Cummings after he put out a plea for “weirdos and misfits” to help turbo charge the government.He was appointed in early . He left on February .Andrew Sabisky resigned on February  amid a backlash against his comments.The former Downing Street adviser, who has a masters degree in the pyschology of education, quit his role over historic tweets.Blaming “media hysteria about my old stuff online”, Sabisky tweeted at .pm: “I wanted to help HMG not be a distraction. Accordingly I’ve decided to resign as a contractor.“I signed up to do real work, not be in the middle of a giant character assassination. I have a lot of other things to do w  my le.” Before his government role Sabisky worked as a forecaster, who predict how certain they are that an event will happen.According to Newsweek, Sabinsky failed to predict Brexit.Sabinksy has five siblings and was mostly home-educated by his mother.He reportedly married in  and first came to prominence with a talk at ResearchEd  in which he asked why educators never talked about genetics.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. She was quiet and aposkept to herselfapos, but was always writing in a journal during lessons. He said: I decided to look over her shoulder and see what she was writing. aposI suck. Iaposm ugly. Fast forward a few years, the teacher says heaposs now in the navy and gets talking to a woman when serving on the other side of the country and they discover they are from the same area. They realise he had taught at the same school her cousin attended and she askedhe remembers teaching her. After recounting the story about the notebook, the woman replied: No freaking way. It is you. Dutch citizen Joran van der Sloot, , is suspected of killing Natalee - who was last seen with him and another man - and dumping her body, which has never been found. In a new interview, Nataleeaposs grief-stricken mum, Beth Holloway, said van der Sloot once claimed to her that he had the teenaposs remains and he would sell them to her. Van der Sloot, whose father was a judge in Aruba, a Dutch territory, never faced prosecution for her disappearance or death, but reportedly later confessed to murdering her during a secret recording. It is said that he made the confession while in prison for the May  murder of his girlfriend, Stephany Flores, in Lima, Peru. Stephany was killed five years to the day of Nataleeaposs disappearance.
